docs.lead_paragraph: ''I've sat in many staff meetings where we've decided that patients should start lithium,'' she told me. ''Occasionally, one of the doctors will say, 'Yeah, but it can cause weight gain.' 'So what's a little weight gain?' another doctor will answer. 'The patient can exercise.' '' ''We just ignore it as a side effect. But then, when I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder, and started lithium, I gained 45 pounds. And my skin got bad. I used to be thin and attractive. Now look at me!'' Tears welled in her eyes.

headline.main: Seeing Risk and Reward Through a Patient's Eyes

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Klitzman Cases article discusses adverse side effects of drugs, primarily lithium, and effect on patients both physically and emotionally; gives personal viewpoint of female psychiatrist and her weight gain and lethargy caused by lithium therapy given for bipolar disorder; asserts doctors frequently have trouble dealing with inadvertent side effects; discusses how patients feel about risks and benefits of drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Mark Moreau was thumbing through HX, a New York City magazine geared toward gay men, and the wording of an advertisement caught his eye. ''It said, 'Be a part of history' and encouraged people to sign up for an H.I.V. vaccine trial,'' said Mr. Moreau, 31, an actor who lives in Manhattan. ''I didn't know anything about it, so at first I thought, 'Oh, you're going to take a vaccine, and then they expose you to AIDS to see what happens.' ''

headline.main: Despite Need for H.I.V. Vaccines, Fear Mutes Call for Volunteers

docs.abstract: General fear about HIV has made task of testing new HIV vaccines more difficult; three stages of studies begin with low risk volunteers and end with highest risk volunteers; first vaccine tested, in Aidsvax program, was not found to significantly reduce risk of infection; studies need to attract more representative group to ensure that vaccine is effective and appropriate for all minorities and all socioeconomic groups, but recruitment has been problematic; vaccines do not contain HIV and cannot infect research volunteers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than 20 years, thousands of poor children who tested positive for tuberculosis but were not yet ill were sent to children-only institutions. There, they were fed lots of milk and beef and forced to sleep outdoors even in frigidly cold winters. The primary goal of these so-called preventoriums, which existed for 30 years, was to keep tuberculosis from infecting children, who were considered at high risk because their parents, many of them immigrants, had the illness.

headline.main: Making the Children Healthy and American

docs.abstract: Institutions known as preventoriums were established around turn of century to isolate children from their tuberculosis infected families, thereby sparing them from contracting illness; concept was founded in 1909 and supported by New Yorkers Nathan Straus and Dr Alfred F Hess (S)

Writing in the June issue of Diabetes Care, researchers say they have established a direct association between thickening arteries filled with plaque, or atherosclerosis, and low levels of testosterone in the blood of men with Type 2 diabetes, which occurs when the body produces insulin, but not enough.

docs.lead_paragraph: The ever-heavier student backpack has been the object of suspicion for several years now, with many parents and some doctors concerned that it may cause back pain and injury. But a new study reports that there is no evidence to link backpacks and back pain. Instead, say researchers from the University of Michigan, the large number of complaints from children about back pain may simply reflect the nation's growing problem with obesity and inactivity.
docs.abstract: University of Michigan researcher Dr Andrew J Haig reports at International Society for Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine conference that weight of children's backpacks does not cause back pain in most children; holds that, more likely culprit for back pain is child's lack of fitness and obesity; 184 children ranging in age from 7 to 15 were interviewed and weighed with and without backpacks to assess possible risks; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Atkins diet gained a modicum of respectability this month when scientists reported that two clinical trials found the high-fat, high-protein, low-carbohydrate diet did not cause disastrous increases in serum cholesterol and even reduced one or two cardiac risk factors. The studies, reported in The New England Journal of Medicine, compared the effects on weight loss and cardiovascular risk factors of the Atkins plan with the conventional low-fat, low-calorie diet recommended by most health experts. Both diets resulted in weight loss, but participants on the Atkins diet lost more weight, faster.

headline.main: Pounds Lost on Atkins Diet May Quickly Return

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses weight gain in Americans and how it relates to two new studies published in New England Journal of Medicine on possible risks and benefits of Atkins Diet; article notes Americans eat more fat and carbohydrates than 30 years ago and, most importantly, more calories, while general fitness levels have declined; people on Atkins diet do show quick weight loss and new study finds it does not have negative impact on cholesterol; long terms effects, however are not known and many participants begin gaining weight back within six months of starting Atkins Diet; drawing (M)

And, the researchers found, people with guns are 16 times as likely to commit suicide using guns.

docs.lead_paragraph: What would you do if your baby was born intersex, with sex organs and external genitalia not clearly male or female? How would you choose whether to bring up your child as a boy or a girl and decide whether doctors should perform corrective genital surgery? A series of new studies and a book, ''Intersex and Identity'' (Rutgers University Press, 2003), seek to provide the answers to these questions. Yet despite this research, the ultimate choices may have less to do with a child's medical condition than with the hospital selected for childbirth. If this sounds like an anomaly in an era of evidence-based medicine, you are right.

headline.main: If Biology Is Destiny, When Shouldn't It Be?

docs.abstract: Statistics show estimated 1 in 2,500 births are intersex, with both internal and external sex organs; historically doctors have made decision and, sometimes without even consulting parents, assigned sex to child through surgery; group of intersex people, many of whom did not know until later in life about their sexual assignments, have formed activist organizations to protect rights of infants; both doctors and activists agree on parental involvement in deciding how to proceed, but activists believe best course of action would be to wait until children are old enough to make their own decision whether to be physically male or female; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The truth about cats and dogs is that dogs seem to be worse, at least for people with asthma. That finding, presented last week at the American Thoracic Society International Conference in Seattle, may surprise many asthma patients.

headline.main: Allergen Tracks Point to the Dog

docs.abstract: Dr Timothy Craig, Pennsylavania State University Milton S Hershey Medical Center researcher, presents findings at American Thoracic Society International Conference that show dog allergies create more severe reactions in those suffering with asthma than many other common allergens; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nestled amid the grand estates of the Adirondack Mountains 300 miles north of New York City is a red one-room cabin. It is a reminder of a strange chapter in the annals of American medicine, one that engenders debate even today, a half-century after it housed its last occupant. The tiny house, built in 1884, looks like an oversize dollhouse. The simple furnishings -- two cots, two small bureaus and a faded photograph of two sisters -- tell the tale of a killer disease and one man's lifelong obsession to conquer it.

headline.main: A Magic Mountain of Fresh Air, Sexual Frolicking and, Oh, Yes, Recovery

docs.abstract: Dr Victoria E Rinehart has gathered stories, letters and interviews in her book Portrait of Healing: Curing in the Woods, about Adirondack tuberculosis sanitarium and its founder Dr Edward Livingston Trudeau; treatment for his patients involved strict regimen regarding food, rest and activities, but book shows a softer side of life there, including secret romance between patients; some historians doubt glowing stories, noting that patients were removed from their families, sometimes for years, and felt obliged to be up-beat as part of treatment; grounds are still used as research facility, although not for tuberculosis; photos (L)
